Summary of audit and implications
- Core claim verified: Under Definition 6 (geometry-aware interior placement invariance), the segment LP is too weak in the two-way model. The stationary order-1 Markov chain on Σ = {1,2,3} with no self-loops (P(i→i)=0, P(i→j)=1/2 for j≠i) and stationary initial law u ≡ 1/3 yields, for every k and r, a feasible distribution p on Σ^k with objective value 1. This p assigns probability 1 to internally proper strings (no equal adjacencies), and because the chain is strictly stationary, all single-core and multi-core marginals (for fixed geometry (s,δ)) are invariant under interior translations. If reflection-invariance constraints are also imposed, the witness still works because the chain is reversible (P = P* under u). Thus q(r,k)=1 for all r,k under Definition 6.
- Rigor check of constraints: The multi-core constraints require equality across placements with the same (s,δ) and interior r-buffers. For any two such placements ω,ω′ there is a common translation τ so that core index sets satisfy C(ω′)=C(ω)+τ. Strict stationarity of the chain implies equality of all these joint core marginals. Nonnegativity and normalization are immediate; objective = 1 holds since adjacent colors are never equal in the chain. Therefore the feasible point is valid, and the LP optimum equals 1.
- Consequences: (i) Solving the current LP (Definition 6) cannot yield any nontrivial q<1 for any r,k, in either the entanglement-allowed or product-state regimes. (ii) Corollary 10 remains true but becomes vacuous with this LP: it only implies P_success ≤ 1. (iii) To obtain constant-error lower bounds, the model must be strengthened beyond geometry-aware invariance.

Value triage and recommended directions
- Product-state (no entanglement): Independence across sets whose r-neighborhoods are disjoint (>2r separation) is valid but nonlinear (factorization). Two concrete tracks:
  1) Lifted linear relaxation (Sherali–Adams flavor): Introduce auxiliary joint variables for tuples of cores; enforce linear consistency across overlaps; add all interior-translation equalities. These constraints are necessary for the existence of a global product-state factorization and will exclude the Markov-chain witness. Start with level-1/2 lifts and test r=2, k∈{10,…,16}. Extract dual certificates if q<1 appears.
  2) Nonlinear exact factorization: Add equalities P(A∩B)=P(A)P(B) for cylinder events A,B supported on disjoint r-neighborhoods (δ≥2r). Solve the resulting bilinear system for small k (≤12) via algebraic or mixed-integer methods. Any infeasibility at value 1 gives a rigorous certificate q(r,k)<1.
- Entanglement allowed: Non-signaling plus geometry-aware invariance is insufficient (witness above). Pivot to ring-level arguments: (i) two-way analogues of LGR’s “experiment” method tailored to r=2, using cleverly mixed distances to force equalities of certain expectations; (ii) indistinguishability/view arguments (φ-LOCAL or round-elimination style) to prove a uniform ε(r)>0 constant-error lower bound for small r. Target r=2 first.

Immediate, auditable action items
1) Insert in output.md a formal proposition with proof that q(r,k)=1 for all r,k under Definition 6 (give the stationary proper Markov-chain witness and verify single-, two-, and three-core constraints explicitly via stationarity). Add a corollary stating the LP cannot certify constant-error bounds in two-way.
2) Update notes.md to prominently record this limitation and fork the plan into Track A (product state, independence-augmented) and Track B (entanglement allowed, ring-level experiments/φ-LOCAL).
3) For Track A, instantiate the first lifted relaxation and, in parallel, a small nonlinear system for r=2, k≤12. Define the exact event families to factorize (e.g., 1- and 2-core cylinder events) and implement constraint generation.
4) For Track B, draft a minimal r=2 indistinguishability construction: identify two globally incompatible 3-coloring templates that induce identical r-views on a positive fraction of nodes/edges and quantify the resulting constant gap via averaging.

Proposition 11 (Trivialization of the segment LP under Definition 6)
For every r ≥ 1 and k ≥ 1, the optimum q(r,k) in Definition 6 satisfies q(r,k) = 1.

Proof.
Let Σ = {1,2,3}. Consider the order-1 Markov chain (X_t) with stationary distribution u(i) = 1/3 for i∈Σ and transition matrix P with P(i,i)=0 and P(i,j)=1/2 for j≠i. For k ≥ 1, define a distribution p on Σ^k by drawing (X_1,…,X_k) according to X_1 ∼ u and X_{t+1} | X_t ∼ P.

(i) Objective value. Because P(i,i)=0, adjacent colors are never equal: P[X_t = X_{t+1}] = 0 for all t. Therefore p assigns probability 1 to the event “ψ has no equal-color adjacencies on edges (t,t+1), t=1..k−1,” and the objective equals 1.

(ii) Feasibility (geometry-aware interior invariance). Since u is stationary for P, the process (X_t) is strictly stationary. Fix any geometry (s,δ) and two r-gapped placements ω, ω′ of (s,δ) inside [1..k]. Let C(ω) ⊆ {1,…,k} be the ordered list of core indices of ω (similarly C(ω′)). Because ω and ω′ have the same (s,δ), there exists an integer shift τ such that C(ω′) = C(ω) + τ (coordinatewise). Strict stationarity implies that the joint law of (X_i)_{i∈C(ω)} equals the joint law of (X_{i+τ})_{i∈C(ω)} = (X_j)_{j∈C(ω′)}. Hence for every core assignment ζ, the marginal probability that the cores equal ζ is the same for ω and ω′. Nonnegativity and normalization of p are immediate. Thus p is feasible with objective value 1, and so q(r,k) ≥ 1. Since the objective is at most 1 for all feasible p, q(r,k)=1.

Corollary 12 (No segment-LP constant-error bound in two-way under Definition 6)
Under Definition 6, the segment LP cannot certify any nontrivial bound for two-way algorithms: for all r,k we have q(r,k)=1. Consequently, Corollary 10 specializes to the trivial inequality P_success(C_n) ≤ 1 in the entanglement-allowed regime and gives no constant-error lower bound.

Remark 12.1 (Scope). Proposition 11 does not contradict the soundness of the constraints in Definition 6 for actual r-round algorithms under the symmetry assumptions of Remark 6.1; it shows that these constraints alone are insufficient. To obtain nontrivial upper bounds in the product-state regime, independence across sets with disjoint r-neighborhoods (>2r separation) must be incorporated, which is nonlinear (factorization). In the entanglement-allowed regime, no such independence holds, so segment-based linear constraints of this form cannot lead to q<1.
